one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 2 Samuel 7:1-7; 1 Chronicles 17:1-6; 22:8; 28:3.
God rejected David's request to build God a house.

questions.questionText: 3. What did David want to do for the Lord? Why? Was God pleased with David's request? (2 Chronicles 6:8)
4. What reasons did God give David for not proceeding? What do you learn about God from these reasons?
5. When have you had God say "no" to something you wanted? What lessons did you learn?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 2 Samuel 7:8-17; 1 Chronicles 17:7-15; Psalm 89:35-37.
God promised to build David a dynasty.

questions.questionText: 6. What were the main promises of God's covenant with David? To what New Testament person does it ultimately refer? (For help, see Isaiah 9:6-7; Matthew 1:1-16 or any other Scripture reference.)
7. What warnings and encouragements stand out to you from these promises?
8. Looking back, how has God revealed His wisdom and love through His plans for your life?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 2 Samuel 7:18-24; 1 Chronicles 17:16-22.
David marveled at God's matchless greatness.

questions.questionText: 10. Which of David's thoughts and beliefs about God are most meaningful to you? Why?
11. What did David recognize God doing for himself, his family and Israel? How have you seen and responded to unexpected blessings in your life?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 2 Samuel 7:25-29; 1 Chronicles 17:23-27; Psalm 89:19-37.
David prayed for God's continued blessing.

questions.questionText: 12. Define "covenant" using a dictionary. Was God's covenant with David conditional or unconditional? Explain.
13. What reasons did David give for his courage and confidence to pray? How does God encourage you to pray?
14. Though not written by David, Psalm 89 is often read along with God's covenant in 2 Samuel 7. From the Psalm, how are God's covenant and God's love linked together?
15. From the psalm, how does God describe Himself? How would remembering these attributes help you in your current situation?

six.title: SIXTH DAY: Review 2 Samuel 7; 1 Chronicles 17; Psalm 89:19-37.

questions.questionText: 16. What did you learn about God, and what did you learn about yourself?
